body: I believe this is the relevant spec: https://sw.kovidgoyal.net/kitty/protocol-extensions.html#colored-and-styled-underlines

Hello Alacritty team,

I thought it might be handy to expand this item with some pertinent details.

Proper *undercurl* support actually involves two feature enhancements; those being: rendering actual undercurls, and secondly colouring underlines & undercurls separately from the character they sit beneath.

kitty I believe was the first terminal to get the ball rolling, with the relevant spec listed by @nixpulvis above.

- GNOME Terminal, and other [VTE](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/vte)-based terminals, added support for coloured undercurls a couple years back via [bug 721761](https://bugzilla.gnome.org/show_bug.cgi?id=721761).

- Vim added support for undercurls [here](https://github.com/vim/vim/issues/1306).

- Neovim added support for undercurls [here](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/9052).

- [tmux](https://github.com/tmux/tmux) staged the introduction of undercurls, first via just undercurls in version 3.0 and then coloured undercurls & underlines in 3.1. tmux [#1492](https://github.com/tmux/tmux/issues/1492) is the relevant issue. Note, plain undercurls require `set -as terminal-overrides ',*:Smulx=\E[4::%p1%dm'` in `tmux.conf` and coloured underlines & undercurls also require `set -as terminal-overrides ',*:Setulc=\E[58::2::%p1%{65536}%/%d::%p1%{256}%/%{255}%&%d::%p1%{255}%&%d%;m'`.

- [mintty](https://github.com/mintty/mintty) it appears also supports coloured undercurls which they note in their [text attributes and rendering](https://github.com/mintty/mintty/wiki/Tips#text-attributes-and-rendering) documentation; [this discussion](https://github.com/kovidgoyal/kitty/issues/226#issuecomment-381665023) may also be of interest.

- Lastly, iTerm2 is currently working on undercurls and coloured undercurls. Not released yet, and only non-coloured undercurls are working in the beta-release as noted in their issue [#6382](https://gitlab.com/gnachman/iterm2/-/issues/6382). As noted in that issue, the terminfos provided on Mac are not as up-to-date as on Linux, so users on Mac likely need to fiddle terminfo databases.

Is it worth the effort?

Yes, I believe so. I would not classify this as urgent (it isn't). But it sure would be nice to have. Alacritty has already implemented a first very important step, that being to render underlines itself. The next logical steps, once time and man-power permits, is to extend that to undercurls and then coloured underlines & undercurls.

Here is an example of coloured undercurls running in GNOME Terminal + tmux + Neovim doing spell check highlighting via undercurls:

![undercurl](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/11382509/88470712-33f9f880-cf43-11ea-9bc8-553ccd446614.png)

Best regards.

issue.title: Support for setting individual color for underline (<ESC>[58...m)
issue.body:
It would be nice if alacritty learns how to set the color of the underline independently of the text color. This is in particularly useful for marking spelling mistakes in a (console) text editor and still keep other syntax highlighting intact.

According to Wikipedia [0] the (semi-standard) CSI / SGR / ANSI escape code / whatever sequence is `<ESC>[58...m`

Other terminals which support this are for example Kitty, VTE, mintty, and iTerm2.

[0] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_Sequence_Introducer

issue.title: Why does Alacritty terminal gets more attention than Kitty?

repository.name: kitty
repository.description: If you live in the terminal, kitty is made for you! Cross-platform, fast, feature-rich, GPU based.

issue.body:
Kitty is super fast. Very stable. Well maintained. Provide the minimal features (split screen, tabs) for a fully working terminal (no need to add another indirection layer, like tmux, that will add complexity to your workflow, or hope that your OS have a window manager that will fill the features gap left by Alacritty).

I understand the point of Alacritty, their reasons, and it is a great terminal but it seems that Kitty has all of Alacritty's strenghts plus do not lack the minimal set of features to make it a fully working terminal out-of-the-box.

issue.title: Add options and arguments for display-menu to set border, border style, and style
issue.body:
~~:warning: The merge base of this PR should be [`afh:afh-popup-style-arguments`](https://github.com/afh/tmux/tree/afh-popup-style-arguments) from #2931 instead of [`tmux:master`](https://github.com/tmux/tmux). :information_source: To see only the relevant changes please compare [`afh:afh-popup-style-arguments` with`afh:afh-menu-style-opts-args`](https://github.com/afh/tmux/compare/afh-popup-style-arguments...afh:afh-menu-style-opts-args?expand=1).~~ Update: #2931 has been applied, so master as a merge base for this PR is now correct ðŸŽ‰ This PR brings the same styling capabilites from popup to menu. To test: * Build and run tmux `./tmux -vv -f/dev/null -Ltest` * Set menu-border-lines, menu-style options and display menu (see `test_menu_style.sh` below) * Use `-B`, `-b`, `-s, `-S` arguments when displaying a menu (see `test_menu_style.sh` below)
test_menu_style.sh ``` #!/bin/ksh ./tmux set -gwU menu-border-lines ./tmux set -gw menu-border-lines double ./tmux set -gw menu-border-style fg=black,bg=yellow ./tmux set -gw menu-style fg=magenta,bg=cyan ./tmux set -gw mode-style fg=yellow,bg=black ./tmux menu -T 'Styled via Options' '#[fg=red,bg=blue]foo' '' '' -bar '' '' '' baz '' '' ./tmux menu -B -T 'Styled via Options' '#[fg=red,bg=blue]foo' '' '' -bar '' '' '' baz '' '' ./tmux menu -b heavy -S fg=blue,bg=red -s fg=magenta,bg=cyan -T 'Styled via Arguments' foo '' '' -bar '' '' '' baz '' '' ./tmux menu -B -b heavy -S fg=blue,bg=red -s fg=magenta,bg=cyan -T 'Styled without Border' foo '' '' -bar '' '' '' baz '' '' ```
| | | | --- | --- | | Styled with Options | ![2021-10-23-101801_905x562_scrot](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/16507/138549065-5711b50b-eb22-47e0-aa36-3f49dd754333.png)| | Styled without Border | ![2021-10-23-103011_905x562_scrot](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/16507/138549185-b0bb8e3e-d409-4861-9be9-2a6bae636ef0.png)| | Styled with Arguments | ![2021-10-23-101809_905x562_scrot](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/16507/138549066-c09ffb31-c528-40c9-b4ac-886414c7d8a3.png)| | Styled without Border | ![2021-10-23-101815_905x562_scrot](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/16507/138549068-09f90e58-690e-4782-af9f-5667955ec091.png)|

I'm not sure about ETA, but I'd probably work on this one soonâ„¢.

issue.title: How to display the curly line for diagnostics?

repository.name: AstroNvim
repository.description: AstroNvim is an aesthetic and feature-rich neovim config that is extensible and easy to use with a great set of plugins

issue.body:
### Question

By default, all diagnostics are shown as underlined in the buffer.  How do I change it to be a curly line like the screenshot in your Git repo? 

### User Configuration

_No response_

issue.title: add Setulc to terminfo
issue.body: Add `Setulc` to terminfo, so colored underlines will be supported by default (no need to use `terminal-overrides` in tmux, for example). Works for `alacritty-direct` TERM.
